Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 01:25PM Jordymom wrote: Nancy, You are definitely not alone.  I am going in for a 3rd attempt at clear margins in mid February.  Many would feel this is personally unreasonable, but this is the path I have chosen. If the mastectomy becomes the only option, so be it.  I am planning on interviewing at least a couple of surgeons if mastectomy is necessary.  I am finding there is a lot of variables in how the surgery is performed. Good luck and take care.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 04:21AM Jordymom wrote: Molly, I know what you are writing about.  I have waffled backed and forth for so many months here undergoing MRIs, core and excisional biopsies and lots of consultations.  Everytime I think I have my mind settled and decision made, BAM I switch my approach.  I think it is a combination of the worry over anesthesia and risk of lymphadema from sentinel node, in addition to the obvious anxiety over the loss of both breasts which has on days kept me pretty paralyzed.  There is a level of mental exhaustion which also comes into play.  However I am trying not to let this drive my treatment decisions.  So I personally decided that even with two attempts at clear margins I will try for a 3rd time.  I'm not positive the inability to get a nice wide clear margin might not be due in some part on my initial surgeon's technique.  He took out a lot of breast tissue on my last surgery but only got a minuscule amount of the DCIS tumor.  Post-op MRI showed the suspicious area he told me he would get still present.  A new surgeon will use wire guidance to the area next Monday.  I may end up ultimately having the bilateral mastectomy but I feel comfortable with the path I have chosen and everyone will tell you this is the most important aspect of your treatment plan. Take time to research and ask questions.  I sometimes forget when listening to the doctor to not just process the information, but to ask 'why' they are saying certain things.  Really ask what is the basis for the opinion they hold?  If your doc says other anesthesia options are a 'no go', then let's hear the medical reasons.  I know it is really, really hard to go back to your doctor and question them at all about their advice.  No one wants to appear even slightly confrontational, after all this is the physician you are going to let operate on your body, so it sometimes feels like a tightrope act dealing with the doctors. Hope all goes well.  I will be thinking about you.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 02:57PM Jordymom wrote: There is an interesting article in the Journal of Clinic Oncology (December issue) about whether pure multifocal DCIS requires a mastectomy.  Basically (from my understanding) for the lower grades of DCIS multifocality is not an unususal component as the tumor is not as aggressive and hasn't completely filled in the duct.  Since it hasn't completely filled the duct there are gaps of unaffected duct between the areas of DCIS.  This is called multifocal DCIS.  The argument presented by Dr. Rakovitch in her onocology article stated that it if the DCIS occurs the in the same quadrant of the breast and depending on size of the tumors, breast conserving surgery + radiation can be appropriate treatment. So in essence, in some cases where the DCIS is continuous and therefore perhaps a higher grade tumor patients would not have a mastectomy because there condition was not 'multifocal', but where it was considered multifocal (and probably a lower grade case with gaps in the DCIS growth) it was traditional for surgeons to automatically recommend a mastectomy.  This opinion/practice appears to be slowly changing. The most important consideration in treatment of DCIS is probably your margin status.  Then a honest conversation with the surgeon about specifically why a mastectomy would be recommended.  Perhaps the invasive component is the main concern but I personally know many women with Stage I or II BC who had lumpectomy. Here are some links information the article: http://jco.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/abstract/25/35/5591 http://jco.ascopubs.org/cgi/content/full/25/35/5548 http://www.breastcancersource.com/breastcancersourcehcp/6096_29079__.aspx?mid=6 PM if you like.

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 06:12PM - edited May 12, 2008 06:13PM by Jordymom Lori, I would watch for false positives on MRI.  I had 3 'questionable' spots on MRI.  One turned out to be DCIS the two others were benign.  MRI's can't provide any positive diagnosis.  Only a biopsy of the area can.  Yes, it's a pain in the a** to go back in for more procedures, but I think your surgeon is wise to suggest at least an 80% probability the area will not be cancer. Good luck.
